messages: 353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:42): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: what on earth does "UTC format with millisecond resolution" mean?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:43): i assume it's supposed to be a number
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:43): 353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320, where does that appear?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:43): from jatinder's telecon notes
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:45): the UTC format I'm not sure about, I don't remember that being mentioned
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:45): but the millisecond resolution is probably because we were discussing the use a monotonic clock value as opposed to Date.now()
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:45): and apparently Date.now() precision varies across implementations
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:45): Date.now() also goes backwards

353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:46): i personally think the right thing to do is to define an interface for intervals that's unrelated to "real world" datetimes, and unaffected by system clock changes

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:46): that it goes backwards, and that it sometimes has less than 1ms accuracy were there arguments for exposing the monotonic clock value as the animationStartTime attribute
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:46): yes I agree
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:46): and use it for all this
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:46): need to find time to write an email describing it precisely
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:46): so that reference to "UTC format" I think is bogus
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:46): cos there are some tricky bits
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:47): Is it just me, or has almost none of the WHATWG cabal voted in the LC poll?  http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/html5-last-call-poll/results
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:48): . . . Was I really the first Google rep to respond?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:48): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: i don't care about when w3c specs do or do not go to last call, so i haven't voted
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:48): I don't care either as such, but the drama and hassle of the poll failing seems like it would be counterproductive, so I just voted yes across the board.
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (02:49): what's the hassle of it failing?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:49): I expect it would waste some people's time needlessly.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:50): people should vote
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:51): going to LC is good
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:51): Why, exactly?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:51): there are some people who may try to create drama over it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:51): why is going to LC good?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:51): I don't necessarily believe in the abstract values of W3C Process, but in material terms:
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:52): (1) Going to Last Call, especially on a large high-visibility spec, can result in a lot of really valuable review feedback
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:52): the SVG 1.2 Tiny Last Call stands out as one that generated a lot of comments
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:52): "The HTML5 testing effort is making some progress thanks to Microsoft, Opera and others."  I wonder how "Microsoft, Opera and others" was arrived upon.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:52): (2) Going to Last Call signals momentum, which is valuable from a marketing perspective
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:54): A lot of comments like this one?  http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-svg/2004Oct/0088.html
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:54): well, in the end, SVG 1.2 Tiny is basically abandoned
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:55): Since momentum is velocity times mass, and HTML5 is a massive spec, it doesn't need to be moving very fast
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:55): the WG is picking up from 1.1 instead afaict
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:55): so Hixie's comment was belatedly applied

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:55): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, there are some worthwhile improvements from 1.2T that will be brought over. but overall, yes, we're continuing evolution from 1.1
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:55): tries to think of some way to nitpick about the relativistic definition of momentum, but can't think of any good ones
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:56): (although I don't see why <video>/<audio> were less approriate for standardisation within svg than within html!)
